properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainy Friday on tap. A Colorado low will move over Western Quebec on Thursday night. Rainfall amounts between 20 and 30 millimetres are expected through Friday evening. Occasional lightning may accompany the heavy rain. Runoff could be significant locally. Water levels could rise suddenly. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-19T07:19:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-18T15:20:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2187239149.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, rain and freezing rain Friday. A Colorado low will track into Western Quebec overnight Thursday. Northern Abitibi could see between 10 and 15 centimetres of snow while the south gets rain. These areas could receive up to 30 millimetres of rain by Friday afternoon. Freezing rain may occur near snow-rain boundary. Be prepared for variable winter driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-19T07:21:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-18T15:22:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1286316537.2020
Area: La Sarre area, Amos area, Lebel-sur-Quévillon area, Senneterre area, Rouyn area, Malartic area, Val d'Or - Louvicourt area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected Thursday into Thursday night. An approaching low pressure system will track over Lake Huron late Thursday bringing snow to Northern Ontario. Snow will begin over the north shore of Lake Superior tonight and become heavier through the day Thursday. Snow will continue Thursday evening before gradually weakening Thursday night or Friday morning. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm are expected. There remains some uncertainty in the track of the low pressure system and the northern extent of the heavy snow. Snowfall warnings may be required as the situation becomes more clear. Motorists are advised to prepare for difficult travel conditions Thursday and Thursday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-19T08:09:54-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-18T16:10:54-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4183440504.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor weather on tap Friday. A Colorado low will move over Western Quebec Thursday night. Precipitation may start as freezing rain before it changes to rain more or less rapidly. Generally between 15 and 25 millimetres of rain is expected through Friday evening. Untreated surfaces could become icy and slippery. Runoff could be important locally. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-19T07:20:04-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system spreading snow to the eastern coast of Baffin Island will bring periods of snowfall to Qikiqtarjuaq for the next 36 hours with the heaviest accumulations occurring tonight. Total snowfall for this period is likely to be between 10 to 20 cm with higher amounts still possible. Additionally, strong northerly winds gusting up 80 km/h will begin on Thursday afternoon bringing reduced visibilities in blowing snow. This may be upgraded to a blizzard warning as the event unfolds. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-19T00:51:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-18T08:52:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3331883315.2020
Area: Qikiqtarjuaq
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Spring storm Friday. A Colorado low will track into Western Quebec overnight Thursday and move quickly eastward. Precipitation will begin as snow on Friday morning before changing over to rain during the day. A shorter period of freezing rain is also possible. Significant amounts of snow and rain are likely. Strong winds will also accompany this storm. ### Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-19T07:35:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-18T15:36:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0367843528.2020
Area: Baie-Trinité area, Sept-Îles - Port-Cartier area, Minganie, Natashquan, Chevery, Blanc-Sablon
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Possible winter storm for the end of the week. A Colorado low will track into Western Quebec Thursday night and move quickly eastward. Total snowfall amounts could vary between 15 and 25 centimetres. In addition, visibilities will deteriorate rapidly in heavy snow and blowing snow. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-19T07:33:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-18T15:34:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2374673891.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rain and wind expected to end the week. Total rainfall: generally 30 to 50 mm with locally higher amounts possible along the south coast. Maximum wind gusts: generally 80 km/h except locally 100 km/h or higher in areas prone to enhanced southeasterlies. Locations: southern and western Newfoundland. Time span: Friday morning through Saturday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin Friday morning, and then quickly transition through freezing precipitation before changing to rain at times heavy late Friday. Snowfall amounts are not expected to be significant at this time. Strong winds will also develop Friday morning, with the highest gusts occurring over areas prone to enhanced southeasterlies. Conditions will improve by Saturday morning. Milder temperatures will accompany the rainfall and will cause significant snowmelt and runoff leading to potential flooding. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-19T10:38:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-18T18:39:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3499134962.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected Thursday evening into Friday. An approaching low pressure system will track over Lake Huron late Thursday bringing snow to Northern Ontario. Snow will begin over the area Thursday afternoon and become heavier through the evening. Snow may mix with rain Thursday evening. Snow will continue into Friday before gradually weakening Friday evening. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm are expected. There remains some uncertainty in the exact track of this low and the precipitation associated with it. Should the low take a slightly more northerly track than anticipated, more of the precipitation will fall as rain and lower snowfall amounts will result. Snowfall warnings may be required as the situation becomes more clear. Prepare for quickly changing and deteriorating travel conditions Thursday evening into Friday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-19T07:31:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-18T15:32:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3981624187.2020
Area: Timmins - Cochrane - Iroquois Falls
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:

An approaching low pressure system will track over Lake Huron late Thursday bringing snow to Northern Ontario. Snow will begin over the area Thursday afternoon and become heavier through the evening. Snow will gradually weaken Friday afternoon. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm are expected. There remains some uncertainty in the exact track of this low and the northern extent of the highest snowfall amounts. Snowfall warnings may be required as the situation becomes more clear. Prepare for quickly changing and deteriorating travel conditions Thursday evening into Friday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions are expected to develop early this afternoon. Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow will persist until early Thursday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: ROAD DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR BURNS LAKE AND SMITHERS The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has continued a Road Dust Advisory for Burns Lake and Smithers because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation or dust suppression. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise near busy roads until the advisory is lifted. Exposure is particularly a concern for pregnant women, infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-03-19T09:57:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2020-03-18T17:58:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3677653748.2020
Area: Bulkley Valley, Lakes District
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions with near-zero visibilities will occur over the next day at Clyde River. Near-zero visibilities in snow and blowing snow are currently occurring at Clyde River. Visibilities will be poor for part of the day today, but conditions will likely improve this afternoon, as winds abate temporarily. Blizzard conditions will return tonight and are expected to continue until Thursday afternoon, when the winds will abate and visibilities will improve. ### Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-19T06:25:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-18T14:26:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2356564359.2020
Area: Clyde River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and blowing snow expected Thursday evening into Friday. An approaching low pressure system will track over Lake Huron late Thursday bringing snow to Northern Ontario. Snow will begin over the area overnight and become heavier on Thursday. Snow will gradually weaken Friday afternoon. Total snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 cm are expected. Additionally, northerly winds gusting 50 or 60 km/h are expected Friday resulting in blowing snow. There remains some uncertainty in the exact track of this low and the northern extent of the highest snowfall amounts. Winter Storm Warnings may be required as the situation becomes more clear. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
